items.text: I genuinely enjoy helping others even when there is nothing in it for me.
items.rationale: Reflects prosocial behavior and empathic concern, core facets of Cooperativeness.

items.text: I try to put myself in other people's shoes before judging them.
items.rationale: Empathy and social tolerance are central to Cooperativeness.

items.text: People describe me as fair-minded and considerate of others' rights.
items.rationale: Fairness and respect for others' rights map directly to Cooperativeness.

items.text: I believe most people are fundamentally well-intentioned.
items.rationale: Social acceptance and trust in others' goodness is a hallmark of high Cooperativeness.

items.text: I find it easy to forgive people who have wronged me.
items.rationale: Forgiveness and lack of revengefulness are key indicators of Cooperativeness.

items.text: When working in a group, I naturally look for ways to compromise rather than insist on my way.
items.rationale: Willingness to compromise reflects the cooperative, agreeable nature of this dimension.

items.text: I rarely hold grudges, even when someone has treated me unfairly.
items.rationale: Absence of vindictiveness is a direct facet of Cooperativeness.

items.text: I feel a strong sense of responsibility toward my community and the people around me.
items.rationale: Conscientiousness toward others and communal responsibility reflect high Cooperativeness.

items.text: I would rather take a smaller share than create conflict over resources.
items.rationale: Prioritizing harmony over personal gain is characteristic of Cooperativeness.

items.text: I tend to give people the benefit of the doubt rather than assume the worst.
items.rationale: Social tolerance and trust are core to Cooperativeness.

items.text: Others often come to me to mediate disagreements because I treat everyone fairly.
items.rationale: Being seen as a fair mediator reflects high social cooperation.

items.text: I feel genuine compassion when I see someone suffering, even a stranger.
items.rationale: Empathic compassion toward strangers is a direct indicator of Cooperativeness.

items.text: I sometimes go along with what others want just to keep the peace, even when I disagree.
items.rationale: While reflecting agreeableness, this could also indicate low Self-Directedness or conflict avoidance related to Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I find it hard to say no when someone asks me for a favor.
items.rationale: Could reflect high Cooperativeness but also high Reward Dependence (need for approval) or low Self-Directedness.

items.text: I feel deeply hurt when someone I've helped turns out to be ungrateful.
items.rationale: While reflecting investment in prosocial behavior (Cooperativeness), the emotional sensitivity and need for reciprocal warmth could map to Reward Dependence.

items.text: I often worry about things that other people seem to handle without concern.
items.rationale: Anticipatory worry is a defining feature of Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I tend to feel tense and anxious in unfamiliar situations.
items.rationale: Fear of uncertainty and anxiety in novel contexts are core to Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I get tired more quickly than most people and need more time to recover from stress.
items.rationale: Fatigability and low energy under stress are a recognized facet of Harm Avoidance.

items.text: Even when things are going well, I find myself expecting something bad to happen.
items.rationale: Pessimistic anticipation is a hallmark of high Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I avoid taking risks because the possibility of failure feels overwhelming.
items.rationale: Risk aversion driven by fear of negative outcomes is central to Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I am easily startled by unexpected noises or sudden movements.
items.rationale: Heightened startle response reflects the fearfulness component of Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I need a lot of reassurance before I feel comfortable making an important decision.
items.rationale: Doubt and need for reassurance reflect anticipatory anxiety in Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I tend to shy away from social gatherings because I'm afraid of being embarrassed.
items.rationale: Social inhibition driven by fear of embarrassment is a classic Harm Avoidance indicator.

items.text: I often feel physically drained after dealing with stressful situations.
items.rationale: Fatigability under stress is a recognized subscale of Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I prefer to stick with routines because change makes me nervous.
items.rationale: Preference for routine driven by anxiety about change reflects Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I frequently imagine worst-case scenarios when facing a new challenge.
items.rationale: Catastrophic thinking and anticipatory worry are core to Harm Avoidance.

items.text: My muscles feel tense much of the time, especially when I'm under pressure.
items.rationale: Somatic tension under stress reflects the physiological component of Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I sometimes turn down exciting opportunities because I'm afraid of what could go wrong.
items.rationale: Primarily reflects fear-driven avoidance, but could also indicate low Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I find it difficult to relax even when I know there is nothing to worry about.
items.rationale: Reflects chronic tension characteristic of Harm Avoidance, though could overlap with general anxiety not specific to this temperament dimension.

items.text: I prefer a predictable, stable life over one filled with surprises and spontaneity.
items.rationale: Could reflect high Harm Avoidance (fear of uncertainty) or low Novelty Seeking (disinterest in novelty). The motivation behind the preference is ambiguous.

items.text: I love the thrill of trying something I've never done before.
items.rationale: Excitement from novel experiences is the defining feature of Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I tend to make decisions quickly based on gut feelings rather than careful analysis.
items.rationale: Impulsive decision-making is a core facet of Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I get bored very easily and constantly need new stimulation to stay engaged.
items.rationale: Low boredom threshold and need for stimulation are central to Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I have a quick temper, but I get over it just as fast.
items.rationale: Irritability with quick recovery (exploratory excitability) is characteristic of Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I often spend money impulsively on things I don't really need.
items.rationale: Impulsive spending reflects the extravagance and impulsiveness facets of Novelty Seeking.

items.text: Rules and regulations feel like unnecessary constraints to me.
items.rationale: Disorderliness and resistance to rules are hallmarks of high Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I frequently change hobbies, jobs, or interests because I lose enthusiasm quickly.
items.rationale: Rapid loss of interest and frequent changes reflect the fickle, exploratory nature of Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I enjoy taking physical risks like extreme sports or fast driving.
items.rationale: Physical risk-taking for excitement is a direct behavioral indicator of Novelty Seeking.

items.text: When I see something I want, I act on it immediately without thinking about consequences.
items.rationale: Impulsivity and lack of deliberation are core to Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I am drawn to people and places that are unusual or unconventional.
items.rationale: Attraction to the unconventional reflects exploratory excitability in Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I would rather explore an unfamiliar city without a map than follow a planned itinerary.
items.rationale: Preference for unstructured exploration over planning reflects Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I find routine work almost unbearable and need variety in my daily life.
items.rationale: Intolerance of monotony is a defining characteristic of Novelty Seeking.

items.text: I sometimes do outrageous things just to see how people react.
items.rationale: Reflects impulsivity and sensation seeking, but could also indicate low Cooperativeness or attention-seeking behavior.

items.text: I often feel restless and have trouble sitting still for long periods.
items.rationale: Restlessness is associated with Novelty Seeking but could also reflect general anxiety or Harm Avoidance-related tension.

items.text: I lose interest in projects once the initial excitement wears off and the hard work begins.
items.rationale: Could reflect high Novelty Seeking (boredom susceptibility) or low Persistence (giving up when not immediately rewarded).

items.text: Once I set a goal, I keep working toward it no matter how many setbacks I encounter.
items.rationale: Perseverance despite setbacks is the defining feature of Persistence.

items.text: I am willing to work much harder than most people to achieve something I care about.
items.rationale: Industriousness and willingness to exert extra effort reflect high Persistence.

items.text: I don't give up on a task even when I'm not seeing immediate results.
items.rationale: Continuing effort without immediate reinforcement is the core of Persistence in the TCI.

items.text: People who know me would say I am one of the most determined people they've ever met.
items.rationale: Being perceived as highly determined by others directly reflects Persistence.

items.text: I see obstacles as challenges to overcome rather than reasons to quit.
items.rationale: Reframing obstacles as challenges reflects the resilient, persevering nature of Persistence.

items.text: I often push myself to the point of exhaustion to finish what I started.
items.rationale: Working to exhaustion to complete tasks reflects extreme Persistence.

items.text: I have always been the kind of person who finishes what they start, no matter how long it takes.
items.rationale: Commitment to task completion over extended periods is a hallmark of Persistence.

items.text: Failure motivates me to try even harder the next time.
items.rationale: Using failure as motivation rather than a deterrent is characteristic of high Persistence.

items.text: I can maintain my effort and focus on a task long after others have given up.
items.rationale: Sustained effort beyond what others can maintain directly measures Persistence.

items.text: I practice skills repeatedly until I have mastered them, even when progress is slow.
items.rationale: Repeated practice despite slow progress reflects perseverance without immediate reward.

items.text: When I commit to something, I follow through even if it becomes much harder than I expected.
items.rationale: Honoring commitments despite unexpected difficulty is a direct indicator of Persistence.

items.text: I tend to be more patient than most people when working toward long-term goals.
items.rationale: Patience in pursuit of long-term goals reflects the delayed gratification aspect of Persistence.

items.text: I feel a deep sense of satisfaction when I overcome a difficult challenge through sustained effort.
items.rationale: While reflecting Persistence, the emphasis on satisfaction could also relate to Reward Dependence or Self-Directedness.

items.text: I set very high standards for myself and refuse to settle for less.
items.rationale: High personal standards relate to Persistence but could also reflect Self-Directedness (purposefulness).

items.text: I am driven by a clear sense of purpose that keeps me going even when things get tough.
items.rationale: Purpose-driven perseverance could reflect Persistence (sustained effort) or Self-Directedness (purposefulness and goal-directedness).

items.text: I crave warmth and emotional closeness with the people in my life.
items.rationale: Need for emotional closeness and warmth is a core facet of Reward Dependence.

items.text: Praise and approval from others are very important to me and strongly influence my mood.
items.rationale: Sensitivity to social approval is a defining feature of Reward Dependence.

items.text: I become very attached to people quickly and feel devastated when relationships end.
items.rationale: Rapid attachment and sensitivity to social loss reflect high Reward Dependence.

items.text: I am a sentimental person who is easily moved by kind gestures or emotional stories.
items.rationale: Sentimentality and emotional responsiveness to social cues are central to Reward Dependence.

items.text: I find it very difficult to function well when I feel socially isolated.
items.rationale: Dependence on social contact for well-being is a hallmark of Reward Dependence.

items.text: I go out of my way to please others because their happiness makes me feel good.
items.rationale: Deriving personal satisfaction from pleasing others reflects the social sensitivity of Reward Dependence.

items.text: I tend to open up to people easily and share personal details about my life.
items.rationale: Social openness and ease of self-disclosure reflect the warmth and attachment facets of Reward Dependence.

items.text: A single critical remark from someone I care about can ruin my entire day.
items.rationale: Extreme sensitivity to criticism from attachment figures is characteristic of high Reward Dependence.

items.text: I feel most motivated when I know that my efforts will be recognized and appreciated by others.
items.rationale: Motivation driven by social recognition reflects the reward sensitivity aspect of this dimension.

items.text: I often cry at movies, weddings, or when hearing about someone else's good fortune.
items.rationale: Emotional responsiveness and sentimentality are direct indicators of Reward Dependence.

items.text: I maintain close contact with friends and family and feel uneasy if I haven't spoken to them in a while.
items.rationale: Need for regular social contact and attachment maintenance reflect Reward Dependence.

items.text: I tend to remember and cherish small acts of kindness that others might forget.
items.rationale: Sentimental attachment to social gestures is characteristic of Reward Dependence.

items.text: I sometimes change my opinions or behavior to match what the people around me seem to want.
items.rationale: Social conformity could reflect Reward Dependence (need for approval) but also low Self-Directedness (lack of autonomous identity).

items.text: I feel anxious and unsettled when I sense that someone is upset with me.
items.rationale: Anxiety about social disapproval primarily reflects Reward Dependence but could overlap with Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I worry constantly about whether the people I love still care about me.
items.rationale: While attachment insecurity reflects Reward Dependence, the chronic worry component could map to Harm Avoidance (anticipatory anxiety).

items.text: I have a clear sense of who I am and what I want out of life.
items.rationale: Clear self-concept and purposefulness are defining features of Self-Directedness.

items.text: I take full responsibility for my choices and don't blame others when things go wrong.
items.rationale: Personal responsibility and internal locus of control are core to Self-Directedness.

items.text: I am good at setting meaningful goals and organizing my life to achieve them.
items.rationale: Goal-setting and purposeful self-organization are hallmarks of Self-Directedness.

items.text: I can usually adapt my behavior effectively to meet the demands of different situations.
items.rationale: Resourcefulness and adaptive flexibility are key facets of Self-Directedness.

items.text: I accept myself as I am, including my flaws and limitations.
items.rationale: Self-acceptance is a recognized subscale of Self-Directedness in the TCI.

items.text: I feel in control of my life and confident in my ability to handle whatever comes my way.
items.rationale: Sense of personal control and self-efficacy are central to Self-Directedness.

items.text: I rarely feel like a victim of circumstances; I believe I shape my own destiny.
items.rationale: Internal locus of control and rejection of victimhood directly reflect Self-Directedness.

items.text: I have developed good habits that help me stay productive and healthy.
items.rationale: Constructive habit formation reflects the self-regulatory capacity of Self-Directedness.

items.text: When I make a mistake, I learn from it and move on rather than dwelling on it.
items.rationale: Constructive response to failure and self-regulation reflect mature Self-Directedness.

items.text: I know my strengths and weaknesses and use that knowledge to guide my decisions.
items.rationale: Accurate self-knowledge and its application to decision-making are core to Self-Directedness.

items.text: I feel that my life has a clear direction and that my daily actions are aligned with my values.
items.rationale: Purposefulness and value-congruent behavior are defining aspects of Self-Directedness.

items.text: I don't need others to tell me what to do; I am capable of guiding myself.
items.rationale: Autonomy and self-governance are fundamental to Self-Directedness.

items.text: I am generally satisfied with the person I have become over the years.
items.rationale: Self-satisfaction reflects Self-Directedness (self-acceptance) but could also indicate general well-being or low Harm Avoidance.

items.text: I find it relatively easy to break bad habits when I decide they are no longer serving me.
items.rationale: Behavioral self-regulation is central to Self-Directedness, though it could also reflect low Novelty Seeking (low impulsivity).

items.text: I keep pushing toward my long-term goals because I have a strong vision for my future.
items.rationale: Long-term goal pursuit could reflect Self-Directedness (purposefulness) or Persistence (sustained effort despite obstacles).

items.text: I often feel a deep sense of connection to all living things.
items.rationale: Feeling connected to all living things reflects transpersonal identification, a core facet of Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I have had experiences where I felt completely absorbed in the present moment, losing all sense of time and self.
items.rationale: Self-forgetful absorption is a defining subscale of Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I believe there is a spiritual dimension to life that goes beyond what science can explain.
items.rationale: Spiritual acceptance and belief in a transcendent reality are central to Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I sometimes feel as though I am part of something much larger than myself.
items.rationale: Sense of being part of a greater whole reflects transpersonal identification in Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I have had moments of profound joy or awe that felt almost mystical in nature.
items.rationale: Mystical or peak experiences are a hallmark of high Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I find deep meaning in experiences that others might consider ordinary or mundane.
items.rationale: Finding transcendent meaning in everyday experiences reflects Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I believe that everything in the universe is interconnected in ways we cannot fully understand.
items.rationale: Belief in universal interconnectedness is a direct indicator of Self-Transcendence.

items.text: Meditation, prayer, or contemplation are important parts of my life.
items.rationale: Engagement in contemplative or spiritual practices reflects high Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I sometimes have experiences where the boundary between myself and the world around me seems to dissolve.
items.rationale: Ego dissolution and boundary loss are characteristic of the self-forgetfulness facet of Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I feel a sense of reverence and wonder when I contemplate the vastness of the universe.
items.rationale: Cosmic awe and reverence are direct expressions of Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I trust my intuition about things that cannot be proven logically.
items.rationale: Valuing intuition over logic for transcendent matters reflects spiritual acceptance in Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I have felt a presence or force guiding me at important moments in my life.
items.rationale: Perception of spiritual guidance reflects the spiritual acceptance facet of Self-Transcendence.

items.text: I feel a strong sense of purpose that seems to come from beyond my personal desires and ambitions.
items.rationale: A transpersonal sense of purpose reflects Self-Transcendence, but purpose itself could also relate to Self-Directedness.

items.text: I am deeply moved by art, music, or nature in ways that feel almost spiritual.
items.rationale: Aesthetic experiences with spiritual quality reflect Self-Transcendence, though intense aesthetic sensitivity could also relate to Reward Dependence (sentimentality).

items.text: I feel a profound compassion for all of humanity that drives me to help others whenever I can.
items.rationale: Universal compassion could reflect Self-Transcendence (transpersonal identification) or Cooperativeness (empathy and helpfulness).
